item.title: Trump Sends Letters With Tariff Terms to Japan, Korea

media:content.media:description: Operations at the Jawaharlal Nehru Port in Navi Mumbai, India. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Donohoe Retains Eurogroup Role to Push Currency’s Ascendancy
item.description: Paschal Donohoe won reelection as president of the euro area’s group of finance ministers, retaining a leading role in the region’s efforts to enhance the profile of its common currency.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michal Kubala, Daniel Basteiro, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe, president of Eurogroup, during a news conference following a Eurogroup meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Monday, Jan. 20, 2025. As Donald Trump prepares to be sworn in as president today, Europe's leaders are bracing for the first batch of executive orders and their potential impact on the region. Photographer: Simon Wohlfahrt/Bloomberg

item.title: Chile’s Biggest Copper Windfall in Years Signals Higher Output
item.description: Chilean copper mines had their best month of export revenue in more than three years in June, with the increase in value outstripping price gains in a sign of rising production.
item.dc:creator: James Attwood

item.title: Israel Holds Rates and Cuts Growth Forecast for This Year
item.description: Israel’s central bank kept interest rates unchanged for the 12th consecutive time, giving a recent rally in the shekel more time to slow inflation and pave the way for lower borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at Carmel market in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Friday, June 13, 2025. Israel launched airstrikes across Iran on Friday morning, targeting nuclear facilities and killing senior military commanders in a major escalation that could spark a broad war in the Middle East.

item.title: BRICS Tread With Caution After Trump Threatens New Tariffs
item.description: BRICS officials kept their collective heads down on Monday morning as they awoke to an overnight threat by US President Donald Trump to penalize them for adopting policies he said were “anti-American.”
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: Brazil's President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva during a BRICS summit plenary session on July 6.

item.title: UK Races to Get US to Cut Steel Tariffs Ahead of Key Deadline
item.description: The UK is racing to secure US agreement to make operational a deal to eliminate tariffs on British steel ahead of a Wednesday deadline when American officials could choose instead to raise the levy to 50%.
item.dc:creator: Alex Morales, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: A steel finishing plant in Sheffield, UK.

item.title: Canadians’ Job Security Gets Shakier as Trade War Harms Growth
item.description: Canadians are becoming less optimistic about their job prospects as the economy struggles to find momentum.
item.dc:creator: Paula Sambo

media:content.media:description: Commuters exit a subway station in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, June 7, 2024. Amalgamated Transit Union has reached a framework settlement with the Toronto Transit Commission, the union said in a statement, avoiding a strike that threatened to disrupt more than 1.5 million commuters.

item.title: Bangladesh Expects ‘Positive Outcome’ With US on Trade Deal
item.description: Bangladesh’s interim government is anticipating a favorable resolution in trade negotiations with the US, after being among the hardest hit by President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs in April.
item.dc:creator: Arun Devnath

media:content.media:description: Container cranes lie non-operational at the Chittagong Port in Chittagong on June 29, 2025, as export and import activities remained suspended due to an ongoing protest by employees of the National Board of Revenue (NBR) over reform issues by Bangladesh's interim government. (Photo by AFP) (Photo by -/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: China’s Car Wars Seen Lasting for Years Despite Leaders’ Angst
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at China’s concerns about excessive competition. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: US Trade Deals Prove Too Complex for Trump’s Fast Track
item.description: Once upon a Liberation Day, this was going to be the week by which President Donald Trump would have renegotiated America’s trading relationships with the world.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: Trump Is Already Making the Next Fed Chair’s Job Harder
item.description: President Donald Trump has acknowledged the intense pressure he’s laying on the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates is, in fact, making it harder for the central bank to do just that.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: A “Trump” hat hangs over a television monitor on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange showing Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell speaking after a Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Wednesday, May 7, 2025.

item.title: Trump Warns of 10% Tariff for ‘Anti-American’ BRICS Policies
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would put an additional 10% tariff on any country aligning themselves with “the Anti-American policies of BRICS,” injecting further uncertainty into global trade as the US continues to negotiate levies with many trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Alan Wong, James Mayger

item.title: Portugal Sees EU, US Reaching Deal With ‘Very Low’ Tariffs
item.description: Portuguese Finance Minister Joaquim Miranda Sarmento said he sees the European Union and the US reaching an agreement with tariffs potentially below 10% that would help keep trade flowing.
item.dc:creator: Francine Lacqua, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Joaquim Miranda Sarmento on July 7. Photographer: Omar Havana/Bloomberg

item.title: Polish MPC’s Duda Sees One More Quarter-Point Rate Cut This Year
item.description: Polish interest rates could be cut by a further quarter-point this year as inflation pressure subsides, according to policymaker Iwona Duda.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Trams pass the Palace of Culture and Science, right, and skyscraper office buildings in downtown Warsaw, Poland, on Friday, Dec. 22, 2023. The central bank halted interest rate cuts after the Oct. 15 parliamentary election unexpectedly brought the pro-European Union opposition to power, along with their promises to boost budget spending. Photographer: Damian Lemański/Bloomberg

item.title: Angola Raises Transport Fares Up to 50% After Diesel Price Hike
item.description: Angola hiked public-transport fares by as much as 50% after raising diesel prices by a third last week, the road transport regulator said.
item.dc:creator: Candido Mendes

media:content.media:description: People take public transport on July 25, 2019 in Luanda. - Transportation options in Luanda are extremely limited. The only means of public transportation are buses, which are run by the Transporte Colectivo Urbano de Luanda. This is a state owned company that runs 40 bus lines within the city of Luanda and the whole country. The system has currently around 300 buses but will expand to 400 buses soon. The most popular means of transportation in Angola are mini bus taxis called "Candonguerios". These buses are distinctly painted blue and white and are popular with the local population. (Photo by JOAO DA FATIMA / AFP) (Photo by JOAO DA FATIMA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Hungarian Retail Sales Slow in Blow to Orban’s Recovery Plan
item.description: Hungarian retail sales slowed more than expected after an Easter bump, underscoring the fragility of Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s efforts to avoid a recession before elections.
item.dc:creator: Zoltan Simon

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Budapest. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

item.title: Top Spain Stainless Steel Maker Wants EU to Be More Like Trump on Trade
item.description: Europe’s approach to trade will need to be more like Donald Trump’s to protect an ailing steel industry from a flood of Chinese imports, according to the head of one of the region’s top stainless steel makers.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gualtieri

media:content.media:description: The Acerinox building, on April 5, 2023, in Madrid

item.title: German Industry Bounces Back as Firms Front-Run US Tariffs
item.description: German industrial production unexpectedly rose in May, suggesting companies rushed production before potentially much higher tariffs on exports to the US.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: A steel mill in Germany.

item.title: Sweden’s Accelerating Inflation Hits Bets on Rate Cut in August
item.description: Sweden’s inflation rate accelerated more than expected last month, knocking expectations that the central bank will cut interest rates in August to support the struggling economy.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Shoppers cross a junction along Drottninggatan pedestrian street in Stockholm, Sweden, on Friday, June 13, 2025. In a bid to revive Sweden’s faltering economy, policymakers in Stockholm will probably announce a quarter-point reduction in their benchmark to 2% on Wednesday, according to 11 out of 14 economists surveyed by Bloomberg.

item.title: UK House Prices Flat as Tax Rise Takes Toll, Halifax Says
item.description: UK house prices failed to grow for a second straight month, as the housing market struggles to gain traction after a tax break expired and a sharp increase in sellers coming to market, according to one of the country’s biggest lenders.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Homes in Guildford, UK.

item.title: Kiwi Rally May Lose Steam as Rate Cuts Loom for Sluggish Economy
item.description: The New Zealand dollar’s rally may fade in the second half of the year, as the central bank continues to cut interest rates and the local economy remains sluggish.
item.dc:creator: Michael G Wilson, Matthew Burgess

item.title: Thailand Offers US More Trade Concessions to Avert 36% Levy
item.description: Thailand is making a last-ditch effort to avert a punitive 36% export levy threatened by the Trump administration with offers of greater market access for US farm and industrial goods, along with increased purchases of energy and Boeing jets.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes next to shipping containers at the Bangkok Port in Bangkok, Thailand, Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024. Thailand is scheduled to announce export figures on Jan. 31.

item.title: Japan’s Real Wages Fall Most Since 2023 in Headache for Ishiba
item.description: Japanese workers’ real wages dropped by the most since September 2023 as inflation continued to outpace salary growth, posing a growing problem for Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba ahead of a key election taking place in about two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Starmer Seeks to Hold Line on Spending After Defeat on Welfare
item.description: The UK government talked down hopes that the two-child cap on parental benefits might be scrapped, as Prime Minister Keir Starmer seeks to hold the line on spending after failing to push through separate controversial welfare cuts.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: RBA Poised for Back-to-Back Rate Cuts as Tariffs Darken Outlook
item.description: Australia’s central bank is set to deliver its first back-to-back interest-rates cuts in six years, stepping up its easing cycle as inflation pressures cool and US trade policies threaten a fragile global outlook.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Date Arrives After a 90-Day Rollercoaster
item.description: The world economy, beset with uncertainty for three months over Donald Trump’s on-again-off-again tariffs, is about to get more clarity as the US president’s deadline for trade deals arrives on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray, Craig Stirling

item.title: French Companies Seek to Invest $947 Million in Malaysia
item.description: Several French companies seek to invest a total of 4 billion ringgit ($947 million) in Malaysia after a trade delegation led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim met with 40 industry representatives in France on Friday, according to Malaysia’s Ministry of Investment, Trade and Industry.
item.dc:creator: Netty Idayu Ismail

media:content.media:description: A Rapid KL train travels along an elevated track in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia on Sunday, Jan. 14. 2024. Malaysia is scheduled to release it's annual gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Jan. 19. Photographer: Richard Humphries/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Seeks US Trade Deadline Extension as Tariffs Loom
item.description: South Korean and US trade officials have discussed extending the July 9 deadline for trade deals in a last-minute bid to avert sweeping tariffs from President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares to unload General Motors Co. (GM) Buick vehicles on a trailer truck at the Port of Incheon in Incheon, South Korea, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Nearly half of the vehicles GM sold in the US last year — 1.23 million autos — were built abroad, according to researcher GlobalData.
